Classification.short_description: The task of categorizing input data into predefined classes or categories, using patterns learned from labeled training examples to make predictions.

Binary Classification.short_description: A classification task where the target variable has exactly two possible classes, such as true/false, positive/negative, or spam/not-spam.

Multiclass Classification.short_description: A classification task where instances can belong to one of three or more distinct classes, requiring discrimination between multiple categories.

Multilabel Classification.short_description: A classification scenario where each instance can simultaneously belong to multiple classes, allowing for overlapping category assignments.

Decision Boundary.short_description: The surface that separates different classes in the feature space, determined by the classifier to make predictions on new instances.

Class Probability.short_description: The estimated likelihood of an instance belonging to each possible class, often output by classifiers alongside their predictions.

Confusion Matrix.short_description: A table showing the counts of true and false predictions for each class, enabling detailed analysis of classification performance.

True Positive.short_description: An instance correctly predicted as belonging to the positive class, representing successful identification of positive cases.

True Negative.short_description: An instance correctly predicted as belonging to the negative class, representing successful identification of negative cases.

False Positive.short_description: An instance incorrectly predicted as belonging to the positive class when it actually belongs to the negative class, also known as Type I error.

False Negative.short_description: An instance incorrectly predicted as belonging to the negative class when it actually belongs to the positive class, also known as Type II error.

Precision.short_description: The proportion of positive predictions that are correct, measuring the classifier's ability to avoid false positive predictions.

Recall.short_description: The proportion of actual positive instances that are correctly identified, measuring the classifier's ability to find all positive cases.

F1 Score.short_description: The harmonic mean of precision and recall, providing a single score that balances the trade-off between these metrics.

Accuracy.short_description: The proportion of all predictions that are correct, measuring overall classification performance across all classes.

ROC Curve.short_description: A plot of true positive rate versus false positive rate at various classification thresholds, visualizing classifier performance across different operating points.

AUC-ROC.short_description: The area under the ROC curve, providing a single score for classifier performance independent of any specific threshold.

Threshold.short_description: The decision boundary value used to convert probability estimates into class predictions, affecting the trade-off between different types of errors.

Class Weight.short_description: The relative importance assigned to different classes during training, often used to handle class imbalance or prioritize certain types of errors.

One-vs-All.short_description: A strategy for handling multiclass classification by training multiple binary classifiers, each distinguishing one class from all others.

One-vs-One.short_description: A strategy for multiclass classification that trains binary classifiers for each pair of classes, combining their predictions through voting.

Ensemble Classification.short_description: The combination of multiple classifiers to make predictions, often improving performance through diversity and error averaging.

Label Smoothing.short_description: A regularization technique that softens target labels to prevent overconfident predictions and improve generalization.

Calibration.short_description: The adjustment of classifier probability estimates to better reflect true class probabilities, improving reliability of confidence scores.

Decision Function.short_description: The mathematical function learned by a classifier to map input features to class predictions or probability estimates.

Classification Rule.short_description: A logical statement or condition used to assign instances to classes, often expressed in if-then form for interpretability.

Error Analysis.short_description: The systematic examination of misclassified instances to understand patterns in errors and identify opportunities for improvement.

Classification Report.short_description: A summary of various performance metrics for each class, providing a comprehensive view of classifier behavior.

Cross-Entropy Loss.short_description: A loss function measuring the difference between predicted class probabilities and true labels, commonly used for training classifiers.

Classification Margin.short_description: The distance between an instance and the decision boundary, indicating the confidence of the classification.

Hard Classification.short_description: The assignment of instances to specific classes without probability estimates, providing discrete category predictions.

Soft Classification.short_description: The output of probability distributions over possible classes, providing more nuanced information about class membership.

Classification Uncertainty.short_description: The degree of doubt in classification decisions, often quantified through probability distributions or confidence scores.

Hierarchical Classification.short_description: Classification into a tree-structured system of categories, where classes are organized in levels of increasing specificity.

Zero-Shot Classification.short_description: The ability to classify instances into previously unseen classes using semantic information or class descriptions.

Few-Shot Classification.short_description: Classification tasks where only a small number of training examples are available for some or all classes.
